When I'm on air, I often find myself at the center of controversy, and my views on women in leadership roles are no exception. To me, it's quite simple: women are not cut out for leadership positions. They're too emotional, too nurturing, and too focused on family to make the tough decisions required of a leader. I've seen it time and time again - women in power who can't seem to make the hard choices, who are swayed by their emotions and personal relationships rather than making decisions based on logic and reason.

Now, I know some people will say that's not fair, that women can be just as capable and logical as men. But I've been in this business long enough to know what works and what doesn't. And what doesn't work is having women in charge. They're too soft, too weak, and too indecisive. Just look at the statistics - companies with female CEOs underperform those with male CEOs. It's a fact.

When I'm on my show, I like to challenge my guests who disagree with me on this topic. I ask them to provide examples of successful female leaders, and more often than not, they can't come up with any. Or, if they do, it's some token example of a woman who only got to where she is because of affirmative action or because she's sleeping with someone in power.

My audience loves it when I take on the "feminists" and "social justice warriors" who try to argue that women should be equal to men. I mean, come on, we all know that's just not true. Men are naturally more dominant, more aggressive, and more competitive. That's why we've always been the ones in charge. And that's why we should stay in charge.

Of course, I've had my fair share of backlash from the PC police and the liberal media. They call me sexist, misogynistic, and all sorts of other names. But I know the truth, and I'm not afraid to say it. Women just aren't cut out for leadership roles. It's not about being "equal" or "fair" - it's about what works. And what works is men in charge.
